utterances: You say you work a 12-hour day when you're doing the show.
And how much time do you exercise in addition?
Well, I do the - I'm on the treadmill for about 45 minutes.
I do have to run because that's the only way your lungs stay sort of flexible.
And once that seizes up, it's really hard to sing.
It's hard to breathe.
It's hard to hold notes.
And I dance and sing at the same time, which is really hard.
And if I don't do that I just - forget it, I can't do it at all.
And any problem with the desert air?
Not so far, and you know, what's so interesting is that I was in the hotel the whole time.
My crew and my girls and everybody, they were out in a place, you know, out in the middle of nowhere, who knows where, and a lot of people got sick.
I think because they actually were outside a lot more than I was.
And I was in the hotel, and I'm the only one who didn't get sick, so maybe it was the Bragg's Vinegar, who knows?.
Who knows?
Laura, thanks very much for the call.
And Bette Midler, I can't thank you enough for your time today.
We really appreciate it.
Ms. MIDLER My pleasure.
Thank you so much.
And good luck with the show.
Ms.
MIDLER Thank you, come on down.
Bette Midler's five nights a week Las Vegas show is called ""The Showgirl Must Go On."" It will continue through next year at the Coliseum at Caeser's Palace.
Her latest CD is ""Jackpot: The best of Bette."" It's in stores now.
She joined us from our bureau in New York.
Coming up, we'll talk about the R.
Kelly trial.
Time now for your letters.
(Soundbite of typing and music)

We received many emails from listeners after a Week in Review segment last week, when NPR senior analyst Dan Schorr spoke of a blockade of hate in the confrontation between Israel and pro-Palestinian activists in the Mediterranean Sea.
Ann Rawlins(ph) of Atlanta writes: I have no doubt that Israel is justified in needing to check all cargo entering Gaza for its own protection.
Please stop adding to the firestorm against this small country.
The rest of the world seems to be handling that role very well.
Uri and Judith Landau((ph) of San Diego add: There may be a blockade of hate but it is maintained by Hamas and its supporters in rockets and military aid from Iran.
Perhaps thats what Mr. Schorr was referring to, but that wasnt clear.
In referring to a blockade of hate, I meant to indicate that the blockade was a result of hate coming from both sides.
If it didnt come off that way to listeners, I am sorry.
Many people wrote in about our story about unemployment in Cleveland.
Marjorie Garner of Denver writes: I too have been unemployed for one and half years.
At first I was embarrassed to say I was unemployed, but the reality is, Im not the only one.
Stories like the one this morning put that in front of the people who are employed and really oblivious to the struggle of those who are not.
Several listeners wrote to thank us for the obituary by NPR's Tom Goldman of the legendary college basketball coach John Wooden, who died June 4th.
Steven Scheinman(ph) of Syracuse says: Your reminisce impressed me not just for what it said about the coach himself, but for what it said about the remarkable man who was his father.
You made clear that the strength of character and values that Coach Wooden exemplified - hard work, preparation, appreciating each day, the art of friendship - were taught to him by Wooden, Sr.
(Soundbite of music)
We also heard from our listeners about our conversation with Zuill Bailey about his new CD of Bach cello suites.

Matt Thest(ph) of New York shares this memory: In high school, my performance of parts of ""Suite Number Four"" on baritone saxophone was good enough to land me a spot in the 1990 New York State Band as a high school junior and a trip to the Concord Resort in the Catskills.
While my days as a performer of music have long passed, the experience helped cement my deep appreciation of music.
Your report transported me back to a different time and place.
Well, we like to transport you, and like to hear about it.
Please send us an email.
Go into NPR.org and click in on Contact Us.
Dont forget to tell us where you live and how to pronounce your name.
You can also find us on Facebook at Facebook.com/nprweekend.
Right behind Hurricane Harvey came Irma.
It slammed into a group of Caribbean islands as a Category 5 storm.
The island of Barbuda suffered some of the worst damage.
An estimated 90 percent of the structures on the island were destroyed and some 1,700 residents were forced to evacuate to Barbuda's sister island, Antigua.
Three months later, Barbuda still hasn't recovered, and it's dealing with some very unique rules about land use as it tries to rebuild.
Our host, Michel Martin, has been checking in with journalist Anika Kentish from Antigua who's been following the recovery process.
That's a tough one.
It's staleness and stillness.
Staleness...
Mr.
O'MALLEY GREENBURG: Sure.
Well, there are few bright spots.
Boston and New York are doing pretty well.
Actually, the city with the best stats on - and this is Honolulu, the vacancy rate is 5.8 percent for homes, but only half of one percent for rentals.
How did you come to those conclusions?
How did you compile these statistics?
Mr.
O'MALLEY GREENBURG: Well, our rankings were based on the data released on February 3rd by the Census Bureau.
And that's the fourth quarter vacancy data.

Basically, we took vacancy - rental vacancies and home owner vacancy rates and we put them together, and we ranked - I think it was out 75 or 80 of the what's called metropolitan statistical areas or you know, in layman's term, you know, just metro areas.
And we combined the rental with the homeowner vacancy rate, put it together, and that's how we came up with our rankings.
Zack, thank you very much for the information.
It's helpful.
Mr.
O'MALLEY GREENBURG: Thanks so much, Tony.
That was Zack O'Malley Greenburg.
He is a reporter with Forbes.com and wrote the article on America's emptiest cities.
As we heard, Atlanta came in at number three on the list of the emptiest cities.
Joining me now to talk about this is Shirley Simmons.
She is associate broker at RE/MAX Executive based in Atlanta, Georgia.
Shirley, welcome.
Thank you.
So, Atlanta comes in at number three on the list.
From your experience, what's happening to the housing market in your city?
Well, the housing market has been heavily impacted because too many people who could not afford properties were given loans for them.
They were given loans without having to provide any down payment.
So, their income was not necessarily in line with the ability to repay those loans.
What's happening to the housing stock then - are these homes just sitting there vacant?
Are they going to - are they rotting or what - what's going on?
They are sitting vacant.
In many cases, we have brand new construction that is sitting vacant because the builders overbuilt.
They are sitting empty waiting on possibly someone to come and purchase, or builders and owners are beginning to offer the lease option as a possibility for occupying the vacant homes.
Is this happening all across - is it happening across all neighborhoods and price points?
I would say yes.
What lengths, Shirley, are people going to to avoid paying large monthly house bills there?
They are pooling their resources.
Families are beginning to move in with each other.
They are leasing instead of trying to sell because the period of time that homes are staying on the market has probably doubled over the last 12 months.
And how long is that period now?
I would say anywhere from nine to 12 months.
So you put a home on the market today, you can expect not to be able to move it for at least maybe a year.
That's correct.
And part of the reason for that is because there are so many bank-owned properties and those properties are priced far less than the homes who are being - which are being sold by an individual owner.
You know, often times, Shirley, investors will clean up in a down economy by buying property low and selling that property high.
But that's not happening, is it?
Not as much as in times past and one of the reasons for that is because there was a moratorium put on the number of loans that any individual can get.
That is being changed as I understand it, but right now the limit is four mortgages per individual.
So, take your business, for example, are you finding that there is not much to do?
Does your phone not ring?
Do you not get emails?
Are you not showing homes and having open houses?
Or what is it like?
Well, I can say that over the last four weeks, my business has begun to pick up to the level that I'm used to in previous years.
However, the first six months of 2008 I did not sell one home, and I normally sell at least 25 to 30 homes every year.
So, my business did not even begin to pick up until June of 2008.
And all of the reasons for it include what we've just mentioned.
There is too much build - there was too much building.
People could not get financing.
The financing has picked up somewhat, and my phone is beginning to ring now from people who are more confident that they will have jobs and that they will have the opportunity to purchase.
Additionally, those people who are in the market are typically first-time home buyers, which is a shift in my market because I'm typically selling to the move-up buyer.
